_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2.1.1	Introduction and Policies
Vopak Terminal Corpus Christi (VTCC) is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  VTCC personnel work continuously to identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of new technology and procedures.  This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations are values Vopak holds at its core.  They are documented in policy and compliance manuals, and in the mission statement, which are available to all employees.  	
2.1.2	Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
2.1.2.1	C4 Spheres
There are two interconnected C4 spheres.  The operating conditions for these spheres are 30 psig 
and 80 °F. Each C4 sphere can contain 179,655 ft3 (6,778,112 lb) of C4-mixture.  Per Vopak, the maximum inventory at any given time is one sphere completely full and the second sphere within its 75% capacity.  Therefore, the maximum expected inventory of C4 mixture at the VTCC facility is 11,903,480 lb.  There are no C4 mixture chemical processes involved at the VTCC facility as no chemicals are produced or consumed at the facility.

2.1.2.2	Pygas Tanks
There are three interconnected pygas tanks.  These tanks are at atmospheric conditions.  
Tanks TK-120-01 and TK-120-02 have a nominal capacity of 179,674 ft3 (9,128,284 lb) of pygas mixture.  Tank TK-130-01 has a nominal capacity of 4,022 ft3 (204,312 lb).  Per Vopak, the maximum inventory at any given time is TK-120-01 and TK-130-01 completely full and TK-120-02 within its 75% capacity.  Therefore, the maximum expected inventory of pygas mixture at the VTCC facility is 16,178,808 lb.  There are no pygas mixture chemical processes involved at the VTCC facility as no chemical is produced or consumed at the facility.  
2.1.3	Offsite Consequence Analysis Reporting
The EPA RMP rule requires that V

opak provide information to the EPA and emergency responders about the worst-case and the alternative release scenarios for the RMP regulated chemicals at the VTCC facility.  Note that the RMP definition of a potential worst-case scenario results in a scenario that is not generally considered credible.  The alternative release scenarios represent more credible events.  VTCC RMP does include both worst-case and alternative release scenarios for flammable chemicals present on the site.
2.1.4	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
VTCC, has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68.

Process Information
VTCC keeps up to date process information as noted in the following sections.
 
Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information (PSI) is a compilation of written processes, and safety information. It is made available to all employees to facilitate the understanding and identification of hazards. Process Safety Information should encompass, but is not limited to information in the following areas: 



¿	Chemical Information is communicated via records of Safety Data sheets (SDS) and communicated to operations via SDSs and workplace safety cards (WSC).  SDSs and WSCs include information such as chemical toxicity, permissible exposure limits, physical, thermal, reactivity and chemical stability data, effects of mixing.  
¿	Technology information is records and communicated via process flow diagrams, process limitation (the safe upper and lower operating conditions for pressure, temperature, composition, flows, etc.), maximum intended inventory, and consequence of process deviations.
¿	Equipment information used on the covered processes includes materials of construction, Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID), electrical classifications, relief system design & design basis, ventilation system design, and safety systems such as interlocks, detection

, monitoring and suppression systems.

Process Hazard Analysis
At least every five years after the completion of the initial process hazard analysis, the process hazard analysis is updated and revalidated by a team meeting the standard's requirements to ensure that the hazard analysis is consistent with the current process. Vopak keeps on file and makes available to OSHA, on request, process hazard analyses and updates or revalidation for each process covered by PSM, as well as the documented resolution of recommendations, for the life of the process.
  
Operating Procedures
Vopak develops and implements written operating procedures consistent with the process safety information that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process.  The procedures related to the covered process are appropriate, clear, consistent, and most importantly, well communicated to employees. The procedures  address at least the following elements:

¿	Steps for each operating phase: Initial startup; Normal operations; Temporary operations; Emergency shutdown; Emergency operations; Normal shutdown; and Startup following an emergency shutdown.
¿	Operating limits: Consequences of deviation, and Steps required to correcting or avoiding deviation.
¿	Safety and health considerations (i.e., SDS): Properties of, and hazards presented by, the chemicals used in the process; Precautions necessary to prevent exposure, including engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment; Control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs; Quality control for raw materials and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and Any special or unique hazards; and Safety systems (e.g., interlocks, detection or suppression systems) and their functions.



 
Training
All employees, including maintenance and contractor employees, involved with highly hazardous chemicals need to fully understand the

safety and health hazards of the chemicals and processes they work with for the protection of themselves, their fellow employees and the citizens of nearby communities. Vopak conducts training in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.1200, the Hazard Communication standard, to help employees to be more knowledgeable about the chemicals they work with as well as familiarize them with reading and understanding SDS's.  Careful consideration is given to assure that employees including maintenance and contract employees receive current and updated training. 

Vopak ensures that each employee presently involved in operating a process or a newly assigned process is trained in an overview of the process and in its operating procedures. Employees already involved in operating a process on the PSM effective date do not necessarily need to be given initial training. Instead, Vopak may certify in writing that the employees have the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities specified in the operating procedures.   Refresher training is provided at least every three years, or more often if necessary, to each employee involved in operating a process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process.  Vopak determines whether each employee operating a process has received and understood the training required by PSM. A record is kept containing the identity of the employee, the date of training, and how the employer verified that the employee understood the training. 

Mechanical Integrity
Mechanical Integrity (MI) is to ensure equipment does not fail in a way that causes a release of chemicals.  Vopak is committed to a robust MI program.  This means equipment is properly designed, fabricated, constructed, installed, operated, and maintained in way to contain the chemicals in the process. 

In detail, it includes management systems, codes and standards, equipment maintenance, inspe

ction and testing, controlling and managing deficiencies and so on. It is not just maintenance, although maintenance is a major part of an MI program. Information is required to identify the code or standard for the design and construction of the vessel or tank and the specific design values, materials, fabrication, and inspection methods. Most of the vessels in service in the US are  designed and constructed in accordance with one of the following design codes:

¿	The ASME Code, or Section VIII of the ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers) 
¿	The API Standard 620 or the American Petroleum Institute Code provides rules for lower pressure vessels not covered by the ASME Code

Management of Change
VTCC has developed and implemented documented procedures to manage changes in the process through Management of Change (MOC). MOC is a tool that continues to be effectively used to ensure the continued integrity of the other PSM elements.  

Pre-Startup Safety Review
For new processes, VTCC ensures that a Pre-Startup safety review (PSSR) is conducted.  A PSSR includes the following elements: 

¿	Confirm that the construction and equipment of a process are in accordance with design specifications. 
¿	Assure that adequate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place. 
¿	Assure operator training has been completed. 
¿	Assure that the PHA is performed and recommendations resolved and implemented before startup and that it meets the management of change requirement.

Compliance Audits
A compliance audit is a technique used to gather sufficient facts and information to verify compliance with standards. The purpose of the audit is to ensure that the PSM and RMP programs are operating in an integrated and effective manner. The performance baseline is based on industry standards and is designed to satisfy the regulatory requirements.  VTCC conducts internal audits or self-assessments for compliance with the PSM and RMP Rules at least

every 3 years to determine the degree to which plans and programs have been implemented. There are two major objectives of audits. The first is to assess whether the management system in place adequately addresses all elements of the PSM rule. The second objective is to assess whether the management system has been adequately implemented for every facility or process.

Incident Investigation
Under the incident investigation section of PSM, the VTCC  has committed to perform a complete investigation of incidents to determine their causes and to seek ways of preventing their recurrence.  The process of incident investigation utilizes a team-based approach involving: gathering and analyzing the evidence; drawing conclusions as to the causes of the incident; generating corrective or preventive actions; and summarizing, documenting, and disseminating the findings. Proper documentation of incident investigation results  provides the basis for corrective actions leading to improvements in the organization's process safety management (PSM) program, and accordingly, should enhance terminal safety.

Hot Work Permit
A Hot Work Permit is required for any operation involving open flames or producing heat and/or sparks. It includes brazing, torch cutting, grinding, soldering, welding and others. The purpose of this element is to assure that VTCC and all affected personnel are aware of the hot work being performed and that appropriate safety precautions have been taken prior to beginning the work.  VTCC has set up a permitting process that requires the date authorized for hot work, equipment involved in the work, a system to maintain and document certification, identification of openings where sparks may drop, the types and number of fire extinguishers, identification of fire watches, an inspection before the work, authorization signatures, identification of flammable materials in the area, verification that the surrounding area is not explosive, verification that combustibl

e materials are isolated properly, identification and closure of open vessels or ducts, and verification that the welded walls are not flammable.

Contractors
Contractors used to perform work in and around processes that involve highly hazardous chemicals are expected to establish a screening process so that they hire and use employees who accomplish the desired job tasks without compromising the safety and health of employees at a facility. For contractors, whose safety performance on the job is not known, VTCC is committed to obtaining information on injury and illness rates and experience.  VTCC screens to ensure that the contractor has the appropriate job skills, knowledge, and certifications. 

Employee Participation
Safe operation and maintenance requires the involvement of both the employers and the employees. VTCC employees are expected and instructed to participate in all the major elements of the Process Safety Management program. Employees have the opportunity to actively participate through consultation using methods such as anonymous communication and employee representation. 

Input from employees with the understanding of the processes are continuously solicited as a source of information in the development of process incident prevention plans and conducting Process Hazards Analysis (PHA), or when conducting incident investigations, audits or other activities. Employees are expected to participate in the different areas in PSM as shown below: 
¿	Safety meetings
¿	Development and gathering of process safety information 
¿	Process Hazard Analysis 
¿	Developing and evaluating operating procedures
¿	Training 
¿	Evaluating contractor safety performance 
¿	Pre-startup safety review 
¿	Mechanical integrity procedure development 
¿	Management of Change 
¿	Incident investigation
¿	Emergency preparedness 
¿	Audits 
2.1.5	Prevention Program
VTCC has implemented the following prevention program release mitigation steps:
¿	Dikes around chemi

cal storage tanks;
¿	Foam/Water sprinkler systems throughout the production buildings;
¿	Emergency communication and alarm system; and
¿	Perimeter monitors

These individual elements of the VTCC prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.
2.1.6	Five-Year Accident History
VTCC has no history of RMP covered accidents.
2.1.7	Emergency Response Program
Emergency planning and response requires employers to develop and implement an emergency action plan according to the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and 29 CFR 1910.120(a), (p), and (q). Another source of information on preparing emergency planning and response is the NFPA 471 Recommendation Practice for Responding to Hazardous Materials Incidents can be used as a guidance to develop safe emergency plan and response to an incident.  VTCC has taken action according in developing the Facility Response Plan (RFP).  The plan has been shared with local response agencies.
2.1.8	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
As a result of VTCC being a brand new facility there are no specifically planned changes to improve safety beside Vopak's commitment to continually improve safety. 

2.2	Risk Management Plan Data Element
The Data Elements included in Table 4 are a more detailed version of the Risk Management Plan elements to be reported to EPA in RMP*eSubmit. 

In Table 4, the data elements reported to EPA were modified by adding "Source" and "Rationale" columns. The columns were added to explain where the information was found or who provided it (Source), as well as the reasoning behind the information (Rationale), if an explanation is needed. These two extra columns will not be reported to EPA in the Risk Management Plan submission. They are for the facility's information and use only.

Included in this documentation are MARPLOT® printouts indicating population within the distance to the various endpoints. MARPLOT®, a software package created by the U.S. Environmental Prot

ection Agency and the U.S. Census Bureau, shows population statistics from the 2010 Census for the Worst-Case Scenarios (WCS) and Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) radii, as determined by the Offsite Consequence Analysis. Note that 2010 census data has been used as 2020 census data has not been finalized or available in Marplot. The distance to the endpoint radii are indicated at the top of each page. The maps have been reviewed to determine receptors (schools, hospitals, prisons, etc.) within the distance to the endpoint. The presence of various categories of receptors is recorded in the Data Elements submitted to EPA.

2.3	Five-Year Accident History
Through communication from the facility, VTCC has not started operation.  Therefore, no  accident meeting the definition of a RMP accident has occurred at this facility as of June 30, 2021. 

2.4	Prevention Program
The prevention program has been outlined in Section 2.1.5.

2.5	Emergency Response Program
The emergency response program has been outlined in Section 2.1.7.

2.6	Management System
The Management System outlines the responsibility levels for the elements of the Risk Management Program. 
2.6.1	Responsibilities for Risk Management Program Elements
The following sections identify the specific responsibilities for each aspect of the risk management and process safety management programs.
2.6.2	Hazard Assessments
The Environmental RMP Administrator has responsibility for:
¿	Ensuring that the offsite consequence analysis for each regulated process is consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39;
¿	Selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMP as required under Section 68.165; and 
¿	Ensuring that the accident history for each covered process is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with Sections 68.42 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.
2.6.3	Prevention Program
The Safety Engineer has the overall responsibility for ensuring

that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program as required by Sections 68.65 through 68.87 and OSHA PSM requirements.  General responsibilities for the Prevention Program Elements are listed below:
¿	Process Safety Information (Section 68.65) - Safety Engineer
¿	Process Hazard Analysis (Section 68.67) - Safety Engineer
¿	Operating Procedures (Section 68.69) - Terminal Manager
¿	Training (Section 68.71) - Terminal Manager
¿	Mechanical Integrity (Section 68.73) - Engineering and Construction Manager
¿	Management of Change (Section 68.75) - Terminal Manager 
¿	Pre-Startup Review (Section 68.77) - Safety Engineer
¿	Compliance Audits (Section 68.79) - Safety Engineer
¿	Incident Investigation (Section 68.81) - Safety Engineer
¿	Employee Participation (Section 68.83) - Terminal Manager
¿	Hot Work Permits (Section 68.85) - Safety Engineer
¿	Contractors (Section 68.87) - Terminal Manager

2.6.4	Emergency Response Program
In accordance with Sections 68.90 and 68.95, the Terminal Manager is responsible for:
¿	Designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility's Emergency Response Plan,
¿	Ensuring that all associated training is conducted and documented as necessary,
¿	Coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and
¿	Responding to local emergency planners/responders when questions arise.

2.6.5	Risk Management Plan Preparation and Submission
The RMP Administrator is responsible for preparing and submitting the Risk Management Plan information as required under Sections 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule. The PSM Manager also has the responsibility for ensuring proper updates to the RMP under Section 68.190, for making corrections as necessary under Section 68.195 and for adequate record-keeping under Section 68.200.

2.6.6	Risk Management Program Communication
The Terminal Manager has the responsibility of providing RMP information to employees and the public as requ
ired under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.
